comments.author: c7i6abc

comments.text:
+c7i6abc (TL;DR at the end)

As you weren't in a rush anyway, I think I have an answer. The idea is you 
use the Fibonacci numbers that add to the number you want. It's easiest if 
you go backwards, so that you can essentially the biggest number you can 
into your sum that won't go over your intended number, in your case 12. So 
the choices are:
21 13 8 5 3 2 1            for 12 you want:
21 13 *8* 5 *3* 2 *1*
21 is too much, 13 is too much, 8 fits and you have 4 left, 5 is too much, 
3 fits and leaves 1, 2 is too much, and 1 finishes it.
What he's done is, essentially, in the nicest most loving and admiring way, 
bugger up.
You can see this in the yellow "3" sheet, where you have the little groups 
that only 3 can make with the fewest possible digits in your sum to reach 
your target. The basic ingredients of a number where 3 is essential are 3 
and 4, and any other number can be made using a five. The sheet should show 
groups of 2 digits, because the numbers on that sheet are 3 and 4 with 
another Fibonacci number tacked on, the 3rd of the base group would be 5, 
which is already a Fibonacci number and so unnecessary. 3 is needed for any 
number 3 or 4 digits above a Fibonacci number, but not 5 above as that 
number can be made with the 5 from the Fibonacci sequence.

So for the yellow "3" sheet, you should get these groups of 2, as you go 
through these bands where only a 3 will do, but you'll see on the sheet 
that 11 is on it's own, and is the only one on it's own (except 32 as 33 is 
out of the range for whatever reason). The parts with 3 follow the pattern 
*3*, *3+1*, 8+*3*, 8+*3+1*, 13+*3*, 13+*3+1*; ect, ect, ect. So 
essentially, you should be seeing the 12 on that "3" sheet.

I should say I notice a flaw either in my thinking or in his entire system 
for these cards involving the number 12 on the "1" sheet, but I doubt 
you've even read this far so I'll spare you.

TL;DR: He got it wrong and this is difficult to think about so fair play to 
him anyway, 12 should be on the "3" sheet and the "1" sheet instead of the 
"5" sheet.

comments.author: Jake Halford

comments.text:
It's cut out of the video, but you see an example for the prime number 
representation at 6:30 on the paper and there are the prime numbers and 
also a leading 1! So any integer from 1 to 42 can be expressed as sum of 1 
and the prime numbers up to 13.
However this representation is not unique! i.e. 6=1+2+3=1+5. So while 
preparing your cards for the trick you must choose only one representation 
for each number!

comments.author: FlunkshSucksAtToribash

comments.text:
When asked to think of a random number from 1 to 20, people choose 17 
significantly more often than any other number. I would not be surprised if 
this were true of people asked to pick a number from 1 to 30.
It's been called the "most random number" for this reason (of being chosen 
as a "random" number most often) as well as the "least random number" (due 
to its quality of betraying the desired property of random numbers to be 
evenly distributed). I suppose whether you call it the "most random" or 
"least random" depends on how you interpret a number's "randomness". In any 
case, I'm not surprised that you got the same number, and it's not just 
because, as others have pointed out, it's likely for many people to pick 
the same number with such a large audience.
You can do a quick web search for something like "17 random number" to find 
all sorts of information and (mostly informal) studies showing 17's 
popularity among people asked to pick a "random" number.

That's pretty easy, just don't pick any power of 2 and you got 0. You could 
easily expand the thing to "number between 0 and 31" and then it's just 0 
whenever it's not on any cards. Sure, you could do the same with every 
single thing you're adding, including weird stuff like apple pie, as in 
"pick a number between 1 and 31, or apple pie", and then it would be apple 
pie whenever it's none of the numbers since only numbers are on the sheets, 
but 0 is the only one that fits the formula of "add the first number of the 
sheets", so it's the logical candidate.

+MrPataraga A better way to do it, with ternary, would be have two sets of 
numbers on each card. The top set are the numbers in range with a 1 in that 
digit, the bottom set are the numbers with 2 in that digit. The person 
tells you whether their number is on the top, bottom, or not on the page.

comments.text:
no, because the person you do the trick with just tells you if it's on the 
card (1) or not (0). when you use another base, like base three, you would 
have to differentiate between three states (0, 1, 2) and the trick wouldn't 
work that way. You could alter it by writing the numbers multiple times on 
the cards and ask how often their number is on them, but i think the 
original one is better^^
comments.author: MRT9393

comments.text: +sirhotofdog I get it now...
comments.author: Some Random Fellow

comments.text:
Let's say you want to do ternary. You get a 1, 2,3,6,9,18,27,54,etc. card 
for however high you want to go. This is because, doing it like they did 
for Fibonacci numbers, you describe each number with only the biggest 
possible numbers. For instance, 12 could be 9+3 or 9+2+1 or 6+3+2+1, but 
two of these are redundant. In ternary 12 is 110 (9+3), and the others 
require multiple numbers in the last spot.

For quaternary, you would do 1,2,3,4,8,12,16,32,48,etc. for however high 
you wanted. I think you can induct from there.

1,2,3,...n-1 card followed by n,2n,3n,...,(n-1)*n card, etc. and only do 
the simplest form of each number.\

comments.text:
It only has one factor. The criteria for being a prime number is having 
exactly two factors, which must be one, and itself. While the number one 
technically fulfills the second half of the definition, it still needs to 
have two factors to be considered a prime number.
